links.description: In Heartbreak High (2022), another local production, autistic actress Chloe Hayden plays autistic character Quinni. Hayden describes good disability representation as lifesaving: “I grew up thinking I wasn’t supposed to exist, and a very large reason for that was because I didn’t see myself represented,” she said.

links.description: Joyful stories about disability like Crip Camp are made locally, too. Thomas Charles Hyland’s directorial debut tells the story of a group of neurodivergent teens putting on a John Farnham musical. It was the first film in the MIFF premiere fund to be awarded Bus Stop Films’ ‘inclusively made’ certification in 2023.

links.description: Deafula takes a lighthearted approach to representation and inclusion. Documentary Crip Camp (2020), which provides a joyful window into a summer camp for teenagers with disabilities, was similarly playful. Director James LeBrecht described the film as a way to share the fun with a broader audience.

start.title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly
start.creator_credit: Jon Kilik, Kathleen Kennedy, Léonard Glowinski and Pictanovo
start.headline_credit: France and United States of America, 2007
start.brief_description: The true story of Elle France editor Jean-Dominique Bauby, who, in 1995 at the age of 43, suffered a stroke that paralyzed his entire body, except his left eye. Using that eye to blink out his memoir, Bauby eloquently described the aspects of his interior world.

links.description: Other Deaf and disabled artists have approached representing aspects of their lives in experimental and playful ways. Horror-comedy Deafula (1975), by Deaf filmmaker Peter Wechsberg, was the first feature film made completely in American Sign Language.

links.description: Like RISE (2018), Jean-Dominique Bauby’s memoir The Diving Bell and the Butterfly depicts the domestic experience of disability – his life with locked-in syndrome. The 2007 film adaptation was ranked one of the BBC’s greatest films of the 21st century.
